entry.title: Join the Data and Analytics Value Map on SAP Community
entry.content:
SAP Enterprise Support Value Maps have moved to SAP Community. Join us now in the SAP Community Groups to stay up to date and informed on the SAP Enterprise Support portfolio for Data and Analytics, ranging from Expert-guided implementation (EGI) sessions, Continuous Quality Check (CQC) services, E-learnings, SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council pilot programs and more.

The Data and Analytics Value Map provides guidance for solutions including SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Analytics Cloud, SAP Datasphere, SAP Business Warehouse, SAP HANA Cloud, SAP Databricks, as well as SAP BusinessObjects. To see our new look in the SAP Community, watch the short SAP video (1 min, 30): SAP Enterprise Support Value Maps on SAP Community

 

How to Access

  • To access the SAP Enterprise Support Value Maps Group, you must login to SAP Community with an S-user ID or a Universal ID
  • Navigate to us via the tab ‚ÄúGroups‚Äù, then ‚ÄúCustomer Only Groups‚Äù or via our dedicated page: SAP Enterprise Support Value Maps

  • Once in the SAP Enterprise Support Value Maps Group, select the Data and Analytics Value Map and click ‚ÄúJoin Group‚Äù
  • Expand the ‚ÄúOptions‚Äù button and click ‚ÄúSubscribe‚Äù to get email notifications of activity within the group
  • Why join and subscribe? To set customization preferences, get notifications, participate in the group and have a better user experience

 

Blog Posts

We will continue to post blogs to let you know about availability of new and updated content in the SAP Enterprise Support portfolio, such as new E-Learnings, events taking place, best practices, and other relevant information for the Data and Analytics topic.

 

Knowledge Base

Our Knowledge Base is a collection of documents, which provide both foundational information and in-depth guidance for SAP Data and Analytics topics including SAP Business Data Cloud. These focused documents organize the Expert-guided implementation (EGI) sessions, Continuous Quality Check (CQC) services, E-learnings, best practices, and more by topic. Making it easier for you to see in one place the SAP Enterprise Support offerings by topic and/or solution area. Here are three Knowledge Base directories to bookmark within the Data and Analytics Value Map:   

  • SAP Business Data Cloud Directory
  • SAP Data Warehousing Directory
  • SAP BusinessObjects BI 2025 Directory

 

Q&A

Use the Q&A section to ask us questions or find questions that have already been answered. For example, maybe you need guidance on how to find best practices and make use of the SAP Enterprise Support offerings for your project such as a BW modernization in SAP Business Data Cloud. The following could be relevant for you: 

  • EGI for SAP BW Modernization with SAP Business Data Cloud
  • CQC for Private Cloud Go-Live 
  • CQC for Implementation
  • CQC Technical Performance Optimization (TPO)
  • CQC Business Process Performance Optimization (BPPO)
  • CQC for Security Optimization
  • CQC for Data Volume Management

Full details are in the Knowledge Base SAP BW Modernization with Foundational Support

 

Events

The monthly EGI schedule will be populated here giving details of the planned EGI topics, dates, time, regions and languages.

 

Request a Call

Request a call with one of our topic experts to connect with the right content and resources.

 

LIVE SESSIONS on SAP Enterprise Support value maps ‚Äì Our Move to SAP Community

Join this live session on October 22, 2025, to learn more, where we will demo SAP Enterprise Support value maps on SAP Community. üîó Link to join / Watch Replay

 
Enhance Your SAP Experience with Value Maps 

SAP Enterprise Support offers additional resources to help you drive innovation. SAP Enterprise Support value maps provide expert-led resources, tailored recommendations, and advisory services - all included in your SAP cloud subscription. Get started today:

  • One-time sign up for SAP Learning Hub, edition for SAP Enterprise Support, using a valid S-User ID (please allow up to 2 hours for processing)
  • Access SAP Enterprise Support value maps for personalized guidance
  • Request a call with our solution area experts for tailored advice

Value Maps are part of SAP Enterprise Support commitment to your success. Visit the SAP Enterprise Support value maps landing page to explore our range of topics and start engaging with us today.

 

About the author: 
Caroline Sheridan is a Topic Expert for SAP Enterprise Support value maps, specializing in SAP Data and Analytics.‚ÄØWith a tenure of 12 years at SAP, Caroline‚Äôs expertise lies in assisting and guiding customers to succeed through SAP Enterprise Support offerings. 

üí°Have questions or feedback on this content? Feel free to leave a comment below or submit them in the Q&A section.

entry.title: Is it possible to update styling rules via scripting in SAC?
entry.content:
Hello,

Here is the requirement. I want to define a custom styling rule within a table for two columns with different color. The table displays data at day granularity. The requirement is to highlight last two days of the previous month. For ex, if my planning cycle starts from Oct 2025, then 29 Sept and 30 Sept should be highlighted. If my planning cycle starts from Nov 2025, then 30 Oct and 31 Oct should be highlighted. I tried to follow the standard styling rule approach but the dynamic nature of requirement is causing an issue. I don't know if it is possible in SAC either via Scripting or by standard functionality.

Anyone who has faced this similar issue, or know the workaround in this scenario. Their comments would be deeply appreciated.

Thanks

entry.title: Master Data Sync in Public Dimension using Hybrid Stories and Scripting in SAC
entry.content:
Introduction

Maintaining data consistency across two dimensions' attributes depending on the ID or any other attribute is a common need in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC).

For instance, if one dimension (let's call it A Dimension) contains master data like product color, size, or type and another dimension (let's call it B Dimension) depends on it, then changes to a property in A Dimension must automatically be reflected in B Dimension.

Under these circumstances:

Dimension A = Dimension of the Product

B Dimension Equals Group Dimension

The objective of this approach is to use a reference key (Default_Product_ID, for instance) to synchronize the values of attributes (such Color_Code and Size_Label) between these two dimensions.

Using SAC scripting, this blog demonstrates how to synchronize properties between two dimensions in hybrid stories.

Overview of the Use case

ConceptDescription
Model UsedProduct_G_Model
Dimensions InvolvedProduct Dimension and Group Dimension
Key RelationshipEach Group member contains a property called Default_Product_ID that links it to a Product Dimension ID field
Purpose

Copy Color_Code and Size_Label from Product Dimension to Group Dimension for members flagged as ‚ÄúY‚Äù

Steps involved in implementation

Step 1: Select the Planning Model

  • Choose the Planning Model.
  • Select Product_G_Model, the planning model that includes both public dimensions.

Step 2:  In the script, declare global variables.

Under Script Variables, create the following variables:

Variable NameTypeModeDescription
GroupMembersPlanningModeMemberArrayStores Group members 
ProductMembersPlanningModeMemberArrayStores Product members 
Update_PRD_KPINumberSingle
 

Tracks count of updated members

These variables make the script easier to read and reuse.

Steps 3: Write a Script Function

Create a function under Script Objects:

  • Name: updateGroupFromProducts
  • Return Type: PlanningModelMember[]
  • Arguments:
    • ProductMembers: PlanningModelMember[]
    • GroupMembers: PlanningModelMember[]

Based on Product data, this method will include the logic to change Group properties.

Step 4:  Write the Script Logic

The actual SAC script that does the synchronization is shown below:

var updatedMembers = ArrayUtils.create(Type.PlanningModelMember);
for (var j = 0; j < GroupMembers.length; j++) {
	var Member = GroupMembers[j];
	if (Member.properties.Flag === "Y") {
		for (var i = 0; i < ProductMembers.length; i++) {
			if (ProductMembers[i].id === Member.properties.Default_Product_ID) {
				Member.properties.Color_Code = ProductMembers[i].properties.Color_Code;
                Member.properties.Size_Label = ProductMembers[i].properties.Size_Label;
                updatedMembers.push(Member);
                break;
			}
		}
	}
}
return updatedMembers;

Step 5: Execute on Initialization

The script used to get members, apply updates, and refresh the model during the app's initialization is shown below:

GroupMembers=Product_G_Model.getMembers("Group_Dimension_P1",{limit:2000});
ProductMembers=Product_G_Model.getMembers("PRD_DIM_2L",{limit:200000});
 var updList=ScriptObject_1.updateGroupFromProducts(ProductMembers,GroupMembers);
	Update_PRD_KPI=updList.length;
        if (updList.length > 0) {
            var success = Product_G_Model.updateMembers("Group_Dimension_P1", updList);
            if (success) {
                Application.refreshData();
            }
        }

Sample Output

After execution, Group members flagged as "Y" will have their Color_Code and Size_Label updated based on the linked Product member.

Benefits

  • By automatically synchronizing the master data, automation removes the need for manual updates.
  • Consistently Keeps dependent dimensions conformed.
  • Reusability Function-based design allows the same logic to be applied to multiple dimensions.
  • The simplicity deploy the features and methods that are currently included in SAC scripting.

Conclusion

This method ensures data synchronization between two related dimensions within a SAC Planning Model.

Changes to dimension properties are managed while maintaining data consistency.

entry.title: Enabling Embedded SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) for Seamless Business Insights
entry.content:
Embedded SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) is a streamlined version of the full SAP Analytics Cloud platform, included at no extra cost with most SAP products. Once configured in SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2 or SAP Enterprise Service Management, this embedded solution allows users to access analytics directly within these applications, helping to drive better decision-making without the learning curve associated with custom/multiple in-built analytics solutions.

While Embedded SAC is designed for ease of use, it does require a one-time configuration to integrate with your SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2 or SAP Enterprise Service Management solutions. Additionally, to enable a smooth login experience for your users, integration with an Identity Provider (IdP) is necessary.

Integration with Identity Providers (IdP)

For secure and streamlined access, you can choose from two supported Identity Providers:

  • SAP Cloud Platform Identity Authentication Service (SAP IAS)
  • Microsoft Entra ID

These IdPs help ensure that users can easily log in to Embedded SAC with their existing credentials. Detailed configuration steps for for these can be found in our comprehensive documentation : https://help.sap.com/docs/CX_NG_SALES/ea5ff8b9460a43cb8765a3c07d3421fe/eceac5a75db64ddbb7afd524058a0a0c.html

For a step-by-step guide on how to enable Embedded SAC and configure it with SAP IAS, we‚Äôve created an instructional video, which you can access here https://sapvideo.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com/?entry_id=1_3w0xwam0

Troubleshooting & FAQs

If you encounter any issues during the setup process, our online help documentation provides a range of FAQs to assist you. We recommend reviewing these before reaching out for additional support : https://help.sap.com/docs/CX_NG_SALES/ea5ff8b9460a43cb8765a3c07d3421fe/319683f2e2b24f8a94eda0fbe9f74271.html

Conclusion:

By embedding SAP Analytics Cloud into your SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2 or SAP Enterprise Service Management environment, you unlock deeper, actionable insights, all while streamlining the user experience. Get started today by configuring Embedded SAC and integrating with your chosen Identity Provider.

entry.title: How to monitor consumption for SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) and its components?
entry.content:
Symptom: You don't know how to check SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) usage.

Requirements: You need to have an S-user and the role of Super Administrator assigned in SAP for Me. 

  • If you don't have an S-User, please check this page.
  • If you are unsure which role you have, please check this note. 

Resolution:

1) Open SAP for Me and log in.

2) Navigate to the "Dashboards" section and click "Finance & Legal".

3) Select "Consumption".

4) Filter for "Business Data Cloud".

5) Click on the measured number to open a card; it explains the consumption by each metric. 

Image 01

 

Image 2

Important reminder: SAP Databricks and SAP Datasphere usage is based on actual consumption instead of what is in the quota assignment. For SAP Analytics Cloud, on the other hand, it is considered the number of users assigned for each SAC license according to the quota assignment. For more information on the components usage (SAP Analytics Cloud, SAP Datasphere), please refer to this documentation. If you want to know more about how the metric itself works, check this pdf.

entry.title: Automated Alerts for Data Action Failures in SAC
entry.content:
Introduction

As a standard feature, SAP Analytics Cloud sends the alerts/ notification  for Data Management job failures whereas for the Data Actions  there is no such alert mechanism, and it requires manual monitoring to track the status of process.

For Instance,  We need to go through the entire  " Data Action Monitor"  to check the Data Action status that we triggered as part of nightly runs. it would be complicated to check the status of each and every DA whether it is failed or successful.

To make this process easier ,

  • The solution involves creating an automated routine through SAC Analytic Apps by utilizing the system models containing the status of the Data Actions .
  • Scheduling the routines at a regular interval so that it monitors the status of DA process and triggers an alert to Admins or the specified SAC users in case of any status other than ‚ÄúSUCCESS‚Äù

Details of the objects used in Implementation

SAP Live System Model    :  PLANNING_DATA_ACTIONS ( Path: Files| System/ Common/ SAC Content/ SAC Content Performance/ SAC Content Performance- Models )

Table_1                                 :     Acts as a source within  the application

Note: 1.This model stores all the data action details in SAC tenant with default time zone :GMT

2. Assuming that we trigger this run this application for every 20 mins through a Calendar publication, so it will send an alert if it finds a failures within the interval

3. Drag all the quired columns to the table considering  " Final Status" as the first row

 

# OnInitialization
var curr_date = new Date(Date.now()); //Get the current Date
console.log(curr_date);

var l_date1 = new Date(Date.now());
var l_date2 = new Date(Date.now());
var min= l_date2.getMinutes();
var hr = l_date2.getHours();
var hr2= hr+4; // Converting the EST hours to GMT
var hr3= hr+4;
var min2 = min-20;// Setting up the mins as per the required interval
// Handling the exceptional case
if(min2<0){
	min2= min + 40;
	hr2= hr2-1;
	console.log(min2);
	console.log(hr2);

	if(hr2<0){
		hr2= 23;
	}
}



l_date2.setMinutes(min2);
l_date2.setHours(hr2);
l_date1.setHours(hr3);
// Setting up the range to filter out the source table
var range = TimeRange.create(TimeRangeGranularity.Minute,l_date2,l_date1);

Table_1.getDataSource().setDimensionFilter("DATETIME_EXECUTE", range);
console.log(range);

var count= 0;
var dims = Table_1.getDimensionsOnRows()[0]; //With assumption that the status column is in the first row
var selections = Table_1.getDataSource().getDataSelections();
var members = ArrayUtils.create(Type.string);
// Formatting the table to print in the alert email
var strTable = "--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------<br> ";
    strTable = "<b>Data Action Name          |   Model Name         |   Process Type                   |   Triggered From              |   Execution Time            |   Status        </b><br>";
strTable = strTable + "--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------<br> ";
for( var j=0;j<selections.length;j++){
	var member =Table_1.getDataSource().getResultMember(dims,selections[j]);
	{
		members.push(member.description);}}
//console.log(members);
for (var s=0; s<members.length;s++){
	if(members[s]!=="Success"){
		count++;
// Pushing the table details to the format table after filtering out the failed DA details			
	strTable = strTable + "<b>" + count.toString() + ".</b>   "	 + selections[s]["PLANNING_PROCESS_NAME"] + "         |   "+ selections[s]["MODEL_NAME"] +"           |   "+ selections[s]["PLANNING_PROCESS_TYPE"] +"           |   "+ selections[s]["TRIGGERED_FROM_NAME"] +"           |   " + selections[s]["DATETIME_EXECUTE"].substr(0,16) +"        |   " + selections[s]["STATUS_DESC"] +"<br>" ;
	strTable = strTable + "------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------<br> ";
		
		
	}
}


console.log(count);
if(count>0){
Application.sendNotification({title: "ALERT: SAC Calendar Sequence Failure Notification", 
							  content:"This is a standard notification on your calendar tasks failure (Data Action or Multi-Action). Refer to the list below for the Tasks/Actions that have failed and take appropriate action to resolve the error.<br> <br>"+"Thanks,<br>"+"SAC Monitoring Process <br><br>"+ strTable + "<br>" ,
							  isSendMobileNotification:true,
							  isSendEmail:true,
							
							  receivers:["SAC User1","User2"]});
	
	
}

Since this code is being written on OnInitialization runs through the Calendar publication and send alert emails

Sample Email Alert:

Benefits

  • Business user to be benefitted by reduced lead time for Data action error remediation; automated email-failure notifications to Admins will result in immediate remediation effort
  • Reduced Manual monitoring effort through automation of alert notifications to SAC Admins on Daily/nightly loads.

Conclusion

This automation in SAC reduces manual monitoring, ensures timely intervention.

entry.title: How to generate the relative URL in the SAP SAC.
entry.content:
Mostly we need url to download the excel template or some functional document from the story so we can download by click on the button, but we are facing an issue when we move the file or document from one system to another system at that time we face an issue to change the URL of the file which point out to the Quality or development system instead of production.

To overcome the above issue we can use a relative url so no need to change the URL again and again base on the tenant we are using it will auto adjust the URL

 

Below are the step we need to follow to generate the relative URL for excel file type

On page select button click event  we need to write a below code

var relative_url = NavigationUtils.createApplicationUrl(Application.getInfo().id);

var fileid = "D5920047F7326A3F92C872224F5E12E";

NavigationUtils.openUrl(relative_url.slice(0, relative_url.lastIndexOf("/sap/fpa/ui/")+12)+"#view_id=contentLib;resourceId="+fileid+";resourceType=FILE",true);

 

We can use the code to open any folder in SAC system  base on the system login

Below is the sample code

var relative_url = NavigationUtils.createApplicationUrl(Application.getInfo().id);

var folder_id = ‚ÄúAB901784C89412AB6FB0FA5679FB7ED1‚Äù

NavigationUtils.openUrl(relative_url.slice(0, relative_url.lastIndexOf("/sap/fpa/ui/")+12).concat("app.html#/files&/f/myfiles/‚Äù+folder_id),true);

 

Step to get the fileid

Select the file and click on the share inside the share panel you will find url of file inside that you can find the resource ID.

Step to get the folder_id

Open the folder for which you need to create the URL in SAC in the URL of browser you will find the 32 digit code

entry.title: Preparing for SAP C_CPE? Here‚Äôs How I‚Äôm Studying Each Section Without Feeling Overwhelmed
entry.content:
Whenever I start learning something new, I like to have everything in order.
Before I even open the first tutorial, I plan what I‚Äôll study first, what comes next, and how I‚Äôll track it.

Recently, I started preparing for the SAP C_CPE (SAP Certified Associate - Backend Developer - SAP Cloud Application Programming Model) certification. Since this exam covers a mix of BTP architecture, SAP BAS, CAP, Side by side extensions, Cloud Foundry & Kyma Runtime  it can easily feel like too much at once. So I created a simple structure to move step by step without feeling lost.

I began with the learning about BTP, and doing hands on by following SAP Learning Journeys, creating subaccount and adding entitlements and services (It gave me a very clear understanding of BTP architecture) and then Developing appliaction using high productivity tools of SAP BAS, Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) because it‚Äôs the foundation of most topics in this certification. I‚Äôm spending around two weeks learning about CDS models, service layers and how everything connects in a CAP project. I‚Äôm following the official SAP Learning Journey https://learning.sap.com/certifications/sap-certified-associate-backend-developer-sap-cloud-program‚Ä¶...

My next focus is Cloud Foundry. I‚Äôll spend about a week learning how to efficiently develop, run, and manage cloud-native applications on SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry Runtime.

After that, I‚Äôll move to Side by side extention on BTP.  This will cover deploying  extension and integrating the app into SAP Build Work Zone.

The next stage is Developing Appliactions in Kyma Environment. I‚Äôll take about two weeks to explore a comprehensive understanding of Kubernetes and to orchestrate the deployment of the applications in the cloud. 

Finally, I‚Äôll study Advanced Extensions with SAP Cloud SDK for about two more weeks. These are slightly advanced topics but very useful for understanding to develop and integrate Java, JavaScript, and TypeScript extension applications for SAP solutions like SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

So in short, this will be my roadmap-

Recommended Study Sequence

Here‚Äôs the order I suggest, from foundational to more advanced :

1.Exploring SAP Business Technology Platform 5hrs (link : https://learning.sap.com/courses/exploring-sap-business-technology-platform)

  • This gives you a broad overview of the entire platform (services, architecture, what BTP is). Good for building your base understanding.
  • So start here.

2.Develop Full‚ÄëStack Applications Using Productivity Tools in SAP Business Application Studio 8hrs (https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/develop-full-stack-applications-using-productivity-tools-in-sap-business-application-studio)

3.Develop Applications on SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry Runtime 4hrs(https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/developing-applications-on-sap-btp-cloud-foundry-runtime)

  • The Cloud Foundry runtime is a major runtime environment in BTP. Understanding how to build and deploy there is critical. 

4.Build Side‚Äëby‚ÄëSide Extensions on SAP BTP 8hrs (https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/build-side-by-side-extensions-on-sap-btp)

  • After tooling and platform basics, you dive into extension scenarios (for example side-by-side extensions of S/4HANA using CAP). This aligns closely with CAP certification topics.

5.Developing Applications in SAP BTP, Kyma Runtime 8hrs(https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/developing-applications-in-sap-btp-kyma-runtime)

  • Kyma Runtime is more advanced (Kubernetes, microservices, event-mesh) and often sits on top of foundational knowledge. 

6.Develop Advanced Extensions with SAP Cloud SDK 11hrs (https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/develop-advanced-extensions-with-sap-cloud-sdk)

This is relatively specialized/advanced (SAP Cloud SDK, perhaps custom libraries, integrations). Once you‚Äôve mastered the fundamentals above, you go here.

By the end of this plan, I‚Äôll go through a short revision period with mock questions and quick notes from my learning.

This structured approach keeps my study plan clear and prevents me from feeling overwhelmed.
I study for two to four hours a day which feels realistic, and the small milestones make it easier to stay consistent.

If you‚Äôre also preparing for C_CPE, it really helps to make your own sequence instead of jumping randomly between topics. The Learning Journeys are excellent resources, but having a personal roadmap makes a big difference.

I‚Äôd love to hear how others are preparing for this certification too.
What topics are you finding most challenging so far and how are you managing the learning

entry.title: New Clean and Replace Feature for SAC End User File Upload
entry.content:
Why do we need a Clean and Replace Feature?

The end user centric file upload allows SAC users to simply upload (plan) data from a file. The new records uploaded from the file will either overwrite the existing records or will be added to them (controlled by a setting in the upload). But what about records that are already in the system and in the target scope of the file upload but have no corresponding entry in the upload file? Those records should either be kept or deleted from the system - depending on the setup of the planning process. So far there was no automatisms to purge the target data area.  Using a data action was difficult as the data action cannot know anything about the content of the file that will be uploaded.

So with QRC4.2025 we ship a new feature in the file upload that enables the system to purge the target data area before doing the upload. The logic applied is very similar to the logic used in the file import in the data acquisition framework.

It is possible to purge the entire target version of the file upload or the target scope can be determined from the content of the upload file. We will explain the feature in detail with a simple example.

How to use the Clean and Replace Feature

We assume we have a company planning the sales amount for some beverage products in various countries. The planning should be done by four different product groups: Juice, Water, Cola, and Ice Tea.

Let us assume there is already data in the system:

Now the end user wants to upload some new data. In the new plan that is captured in the file we only have data for two countries - Argentina and Brazil.

[Note: as in the current plan we do not care about product yet we will post the data to the product '#'.]

Let us configure a file upload for this file and model and add a starter to our story. As this is a well know functionality we do not describe in detail how to perform this task. You can find the details also in the following blog: 

New End User File Upload in SAP Analytics Cloud QRC3 2024 

Let us have a look at the result of the upload:

As we can see the data for Brazil has been overwritten whereas for Argentina we still see the two 'old' records (Cola and Ice Tea) that could not been overwritten by any records from the file.

Let us revert the data changes and go back to the modeling to use the new clean and replace feature. We change to the data management tab, find our file upload, and change the settings.

In the view of the upload details we open the settings screen.

Now we change the import settings to 'Clean and replace subset of data'.

If we do not select any dimension for scope, the system will delete all data in the target version of the upload. As this might be unexpected, the system shows the above information.

In our case we do NOT want to delete all data in the target version. There is data for other countries (like Canada or Mexico) that should not be clear as no data for these countries is uploaded. But we DO upload data for Argentina and Brazil and want to make sure that in the result we will only see the uploaded data for these two countries. Thus we choose 'Country' as a dimension for the replacement scope.

When we now run the upload the system will inspect the data contained in the file for the available values for the dimension country. As there are records for Argentina and Brazil, the system runs a delete action for all records with the countries Argentina and Brazil in the target version, and then loads the data from the file into the system. Data booked for other countries is not be affected.

Please keep in mind that you can choose multiple dimensions for the scope. In this case the system will collect the corresponding combinations and will clean the target area accordingly.

Please make sure to not just save the changed file upload job but move to the last screen of the setup and press 'Finish'.

Now we can open our story again and run the new file upload with the same file as above.

As we can see the two additional records for Argentina have been removed, the data for Brazil has been updated as before, and NO changes have been done to any data for Canada or other countries.

entry.title: Evolution of Data and Analytics with SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
Introduction to Business Data Cloud:

SAP Business Data Cloud was introduced on February 13 2025 as Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) solution fully managed by SAP. SAP Business Data Cloud is a data & analytics platform that harmonizes all data from SAP and non-SAP sources into a unified semantic layer of trusted data that governs, connects and share data securely across systems or cloud. By integrating powerful functionality of SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud, and SAP Databricks and SAP Business Warehouse. It empowers businesses to break data silos to power advanced AI and analytics.

Why was Business data cloud introduced?

  • To get easier access to SAP data without the need for complex data preparation steps such as extraction, building semantics, transformation and loading data for analytics.
  • To get access to all SAP data from all Line of Business (LoB) applications, such as SAP S/4HANA, SAP SuccessFactors and SAP Ariba without the need of 3rd party connector & tool.
  • To get a unified business view of the data regardless of which SAP application it originated from without making harmonization difficult and holds its original business context without any change.
  • To accelerate AI with trusted and secure data that they can use to build reliable AI applications to accelerate innovation and insights with AI.
  • To get faster access to SAP data insights by removing data preparation and dashboard building steps.
  • To get a Simplified Landscape by reducing multiple tools, silos and complex tasks of manual data preparation, development and analytics.

Key Features & Capabilities of Business Data Cloud: 

SAP Business Data Cloud Key Innovation of out-of-the-box components

  • Intelligent Applications: Intelligent Applications are predefined, SAP-managed dashboards for analytics based on underlying Data Products and models.
  • Data Products: Create and share governed, reusable data products that deliver consistent, high-quality business information across teams and systems.
  • BDC Cockpit: Centrally manage your data products, monitor usage, and enforce governance policies, all from one intuitive interface.

SAP Business Data Cloud Integrated Software components:

  • SAP Datasphere: to provide the data integration and modelling.
  • SAP Analytics Cloud: to provide the analysis and planning.
  • SAP Databricks: to provide AI and machine learning enhancements.
  • SAP BW/BW4HANA: can be used as a data source for datasphere & databricks.

SAP Business Data Cloud is built on SAP Business Technology Platform:

  • Unified Customer Landscape used to connect the SAP Business Data Cloud components.
  • SAP HANA Cloud provides the data storage layer.
  • SAP Security and Compliance to manage access and permissions and governs regulatory compliance.
  • SAP Development & Integration to provide developer tools for modelling & data Integration
  • SAP AI & Analytics to provide advanced analytics and AI powered insights.

SAP Business Data Cloud Architecture:

  • Source System layer: It harmonizes all data from SAP and non-SAP sources, into a unified semantic layer of trusted data, to power advanced analytics and to build AI applications.
  • Foundation Service Layer: This layer replicates and harmonizes data from the source systems to produce curated, governed Data Products that retain their original business context. Data products are grouped by Data Packages to make it easy to discover them and to activate them. This data is stored in a hyper scaler environment using SAP HANA Cloud and Data Lake files.
  • Business Data Fabric Layer: It combines the strengths of SAP Datasphere, SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), and SAP Business Warehouse (BW) capabilities, enhanced by the Databricks platform to unify an organization with SAP and Non ‚Äì SAP and third-party data into a single, trusted foundation model.
  • SAP Datasphere is the technological foundation for the business data fabric within BDC. It integrates, transforms, and enriches data from SAP and non-SAP sources into powerful semantic models. Data can be replicated into Datasphere for faster performance or accessed virtually from its source, allowing for flexible management of a hybrid data landscape.
  • SAP Databricks is an Advanced AI and machine learning technology. It provides a pro-code environment for data engineers and AI developers to build, train, and deploy custom AI and ML models using the rich, semantically aware data from SAP applications.
  • SAP Business Warehouse (BW) or BW/4HANA: For customers with existing on-premises SAP Business Warehouse (BW) or BW/4HANA systems, this component provides a modernization path within the Business Data Fabric. A Data Product Generator can be used to convert BW Info Provider data into cloud-ready data products, which can then be consumed by Datasphere for analytics or by Databricks for AI/ML.
  • SAP Business Data Cockpit: SAP Business Data Cloud cockpit allows you to browse and find pre delivered Intelligent Applications and data products, install Intelligent Applications, and share data products with SAP Datasphere & Databricks to enable analytics & enrich with AI and machine learning capabilities.
  • Intelligent Application Layer: It‚Äôs a unified semantic layer of trusted data, to power advanced AI & Analytics.
  • SAP Analytical Cloud: Using SAP Analytics Cloud, business users can run ad-hoc analysis, explore the provided data with AI-driven chat capabilities, or act on their insights with AI-driven suggestions, bridging the gap between analytics and their end-to-end business processes.
  • Intelligent Application: SAP Business Data Cloud Intelligent Applications are used to provide the required dashboard in out-of-the-box reporting scenarios with its advanced visualization and planning functions
  • Joule: Joule uses natural language processing to interact, access insights, and perform tasks across SAP and third-party applications. It uses "agents" and "skills" to automate multi-step workflows and provide contextual assistance.

How SAP Business Data Cloud work as one domain model:

Scenario 1: Out-of-the-Box model with Datasphere

Step 1: The first step is to identify the right intelligent application for your business scenario, In SAP Business Data Cloud cockpit search for available intelligent application and install the one that meets your requirement.

Step 2: When intelligent application installation is initiated the relevant business data that has already been bundled into a package in your business application is accessed and replicated to the Foundation Services of SAP Business Data Cloud.

Step 3: Inside the Foundation Services, the replicated business data is harmonized with other data packages from different business applications such as SAP SuccessFactors the data is transformed and enriched to become a data product. The data is now ready to be used as the basis for analysis.

Step 4: In SAP Datasphere all artifacts necessary for the analysis are now automatically generated on top of the Data Product. 

Step 5: Visual representations of the insights are automatically generated and made available in the intelligent application dashboard.

 Scenario 2:  AI and machine learning enhancement by Databricks

Step 1: The first step is to identify the right intelligent application for your business scenario, In SAP Business Data Cloud cockpit search for available intelligent application and install the one that meets your requirement.

Step 2: When intelligent application installation is initiated the relevant business data that has already been bundled into a package in your business application is accessed and replicated to the Foundation Services of SAP Business Data Cloud.

Step 3: Inside the Foundation Services, the replicated business data is harmonized with other data packages from different business applications such as SAP SuccessFactors the data is transformed and enriched to become a data product. The data is now ready to be used as the basis for analysis.

Step 4: In SAP Datasphere all artifacts necessary for the analysis are now automatically generated on top of the Data Product. 

Step 5: Visual representations of the insights are automatically generated and made available in the intelligent application dashboard.

Step 6: Integration of SAP Databricks

It is possible to extend the results shown in the dashboard with machine learning and AI based Insights, to do so use the SAP business data cockpit to share data product with databricks,

In SAP Databricks AI and Machine learning techniques are used to generate the desired result, this results then shared back to the data model and extend your dashboard with AI and Machine learning insights.

Scenario 2:  : Integration of SAP BW & SAP Analytical Cloud

Step 1: The first step is to identify the right intelligent application for your business scenario, In SAP BDC cockpit search for available intelligent application and install the one that meets your requirement.

Step 2: When intelligent application installation is initiated the relevant business data that has already been bundled into a package in your business application is accessed and replicated to the Foundation Services of SAP Business Data Cloud.

Step 3: Inside the Foundation Services, the replicated business data is harmonized with other data packages from different business applications such as SAP SuccessFactors the data is transformed and enriched to become a data product. The data is now ready to be used as the basis for analysis.

Step 4: In SAP Datasphere all artifacts necessary for the analysis are now automatically generated on top of the Data Product. 

Step 5: This is where the integration of your third-party data comes into play. The advanced integration and data modelling capabilities of SAP Datasphere allow you to integrate your third-party data into the out-of-the-box data model.

Step 6: Integration of SAP BW

It is also possible to integrate your existing objects from SAP BW/4HANA into SAP Business Data Cloud. With a dedicated data provisioning tool, you can onboard your SAP BW objects into SAP Datasphere and combine them with the existing data model.

Step 7: Integration of SAP Analytical Cloud 

SAP Business Data Cloud provides a wide range of consumption options on top of your data model. Use the AI-based Just Ask feature in SAP Analytics Cloud. The power of its natural language processing allows you to request information from your data model simply by typing a question about your data. Answers are instantly displayed in the most appropriate format.

Role of Source system & Data product in BDC:

Role of Datasphere in BDC:

 Role of Databricks in BDC:

 Role of BW in BDC:

 Role of SAC in BDC:

 Role of Intelligent Application Dashboard & Joule in BDC:

 
Use Case of Business Data Cloud:

SAP Business Data Cloud can handle many use-cases including:

  • Data Integration & Modelling 
  • Data Governance and Compliance 
  • Development of AI and machine learning models
  • Data Warehousing
  • Planning and BI 
  • Development of intelligent applications to support all business processes.
  • End-to-end data lifecycle management by SAP 

SAP Business Data Cloud reaches all personas of the organization.

Conclusion: 

Data from all SAP applications is combined and made available to the businesses under a single domain model. With SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP has reached the next level of data and analytics evolution to tackle challenges and enables businesses to seamlessly integrate, harmonize, and analyse data from multiple sources, transforming raw data into valuable insights with advanced AI and analytics. 

By adopting the latest 2025 features, organizations can accelerate analytics, improve decision-making, and prepare for AI-driven innovation.

Reference:

Learning Journey: https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/exploring-sap-business-data-cloud
Live Session : https://learning.sap.com/live-sessions/overview-of-sap-business-data-cloud
SAP Help Document : https://help.sap.com/docs/business-data-cloud
GenAI Assistance : Assistance in drafting the structure of blog.

entry.title: Using Embedded SAC to Analyze cross-feature Sales & Service Scenarios
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs data-driven world, businesses need instant access to actionable insights that can guide smarter decisions. For organizations using SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2 or SAP Enterprise Service Management, the Embedded SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) capabilities deliver just that‚Äîenabling seamless, cross-feature analysis directly within your operational systems.

Embedded SAC allows business and admin users to design both simple and complex queries across multiple data sources. Whether you‚Äôre analyzing sales performance, service operations, or end-to-end process flows, Embedded SAC helps you visualize and understand your data‚Äîwithout needing external analytics tools.

Simplify Analytics with Query Designer

At the core of this capability lies the Query Designer‚Äîa powerful tool that provides access to all available data sources within your SAP Sales & Service Cloud V2 or SAP Enterprise Service Management environment.

With Query Designer, you can:

  • Explore master and transactional data sources
  • View how these data sources are pre-joined and delivered out of the box
  • Build custom cross-feature queries tailored to your business needs

SAP provides detailed documentation on how to view and link your data sources through the Query Designer. You can explore it here.

Creating Custom Joins Between Data Sources

Beyond standard joins, admin users can define custom joins between data sources that are not automatically linked. This is achieved using the ‚ÄúJoins‚Äù dialog in the Query Designer‚Äîaccessible from the toolbar or via contextual links within the interface, as illustrated in this video: https://sapvideo.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com/?entry_id=1_4njrmc5o

Using this feature, you can connect data sources based on:

  • Primary key fields, or
  • Extension fields that function as keys

For more details on creating Free Joins, refer to SAP‚Äôs documentation here.

There are two primary join types available:

  • All Primary Data (Left-Outer Join) ‚Äì retains all records from the primary dataset
  • Intersecting Data (Inner Join) ‚Äì includes only records common to both datasets

 Analyzing End-to-End Business Processes

Where this feature truly stands out is in its ability to link data sources along process chains‚Äîenabling comprehensive analysis across parts of the ‚ÄúLead to Cash‚Äù or ‚ÄúService to Cash‚Äù flows which are supported within SAP Sales Cloud V2 or SAP Service Cloud V2.

You can achieve this by creating joins between related entities such as:

  • Lead Related Object
  • Opportunity Related Entity
  • Case Related Object

To determine which data sources can be joined, execute these related data sources and review fields such as ‚ÄúRelated Entity Type‚Äù. This approach helps you map potential joins and build a holistic view of your business processes.

Building Complex Queries for Deep Insights

Once you‚Äôve defined your joins, you can integrate them within the main Query Designer pane to create multi-layered, complex queries. For example, you might design a query that analyzes all related entities of a Lead‚Äîoffering a complete perspective on how leads progress through your sales pipeline.

The result? A unified, insightful view of your operational data that empowers business leaders to make informed decisions faster, as can been seen in the complex data model below.

Conclusion

With Embedded SAP Analytics Cloud, you‚Äôre not just visualizing data‚Äîyou‚Äôre unlocking a deeper understanding of your business. From standard dashboards to complex process analyses, this powerful embedded capability helps organizations drive agility, efficiency, and growth.

By leveraging the Query Designer and custom join capabilities, CRM administrators and business users alike can transform raw data into meaningful, actionable insights‚Äîdirectly within the SAP ecosystem.

entry.title: SAP Work Zone vs. Analytics Cloud vs. Fiori Launchpad ‚Äì Unified Analytics Comparison (Decision Tree)
entry.content:
In today's data driven world, enterprises need an intuitive and efficient digital workspace that unites business processes, analytics, and collaboration. SAP offers several powerful solutions like SAP Work Zone, SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), and SAP Fiori Launchpad, while many organizations also extend their ecosystems with non-SAP BI tools such as Microsoft Power BI and Tableau. Selecting the right entry point depends on factors like data architecture, user experience, and the level of integration needed between SAP and non-SAP systems.

With more than 15 years of experience across SAP Analytics and Business Intelligence implementations, I have witnessed how organizations evolve their analytics strategies from siloed reporting to fully integrated decision environments. Through these diverse engagements, it is clear that tools like SAP Work Zone, SAC, Fiori Launchpad, and external BI platforms can coexist to deliver a unified, connected, and scalable analytics landscape. When combined with modern data platforms like Snowflake or SAP Datasphere / SAP Business Data Cloud(BDC), they empower enterprises to turn information into real-time insight.

Let's explore how each of these tools fits within a unified analytics ecosystem and how organizations can determine the right combination to maximize business value.

The Contenders: A Quick Overview

  • SAP Fiori Launchpad: The gateway to SAP applications, offering a role based, personalized user experience.
  • SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC): SAP's flagship analytics platform, combining BI, planning, and predictive capabilities in one solution.
  • SAP Work Zone: A digital workplace that integrates SAP and non-SAP applications, fostering collaboration and productivity.
  • Non-SAP BI Tools (Power BI, Tableau): Industry leading analytics platforms known for flexibility and advanced visualization.

SAP Fiori Launchpad: The Trusted Entry Point

SAP Fiori Launchpad has been a cornerstone of SAP's user experience strategy. It is the go to interface for accessing SAP S/4HANA FICO and other SAP applications.

  • Strengths:
    • Role based access to transactional applications and operational data.
    • Seamless integration with SAP systems.
    • Consistent, intuitive user experience.
  • Limitations:
    • Limited to SAP applications, no native support for non-SAP tools.
    • Lacks advanced analytics and collaboration features.
  • Best For: Organizations that primarily use SAP systems and need a streamlined interface for transactional workflows.

SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC): The All-in-One Analytics Powerhouse

SAP Analytics Cloud is SAP's answer to modern analytics needs. It combines BI, planning, and predictive analytics in a single cloud based platform.

  • Strengths:
    • Unified platform for reporting, dashboards and predictive analytics.
    • Deep integration with SAP source systems like SAP S/4HANA .
    • Built-in collaboration features for team based planning.
  • Limitations:
    • Limited flexibility for non-SAP data sources compared to tools like Power BI or Tableau.
    • Steeper learning curve for non-SAP users.
  • Best For: Organizations heavily invested in SAP systems that want a single platform for analytics and planning.

SAP Work Zone: The Digital Workplace Revolution

SAP Work Zone is a relatively new addition to the SAP ecosystem, designed to create a unified digital workplace. It integrates SAP and non-SAP applications, making it a versatile tool for modern enterprises.

  • Strengths:
    • Unified access to SAP and non-SAP applications.
    • Built-in collaboration tools like chat, news feeds, and document sharing.
    • Customizable workspaces for teams and projects.
  • Limitations:
    • May be overkill for organizations that only need analytics or transactional access.
    • Requires additional configuration for seamless integration with non-SAP tools.
  • Best For: Organizations looking to enhance collaboration and provide a single point of access for SAP and non-SAP tools.

SAP Work Zone, together with the SAP Analytics Cloud Catalog, now carries forward and enhances the capabilities of the earlier SAP Analytics Hub. While Analytics Hub focused primarily on report cataloging, Work Zone extends that vision into a full digital workplace integrating analytics, applications, and collaboration in a single experience.

Non-SAP BI Tools: Power BI and Tableau

While SAP tools excel in their native ecosystem, non-SAP BI tools like Microsoft Power BI and Tableau offer unmatched flexibility and visualization capabilities.

  • Strengths:
    • Superior data visualization and user friendly interfaces.
    • Extensive connectivity to non-SAP data sources like Snowflake, AWS, and Google BigQuery.
    • Strong community support and third party integrations.
  • Limitations:
    • Limited native integration with SAP systems.
    • May require additional middleware for seamless data flow.
  • Best For: Organizations with diverse data sources that prioritize visualization and flexibility over deep SAP integration.

The Hybrid Approach: SAC for SAP, Power BI for Non-SAP

Across several SAP Analytics implementations, a hybrid approach has consistently proven effective for unifying enterprise reporting.
SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) is typically used for SAP source systems, leveraging its deep integration with SAP S/4HANA, along with robust planning capabilities.
Microsoft Power BI complements this by connecting to non-SAP systems such as Snowflake, offering flexibility, advanced visualization and ease of consumption for broader business audiences.

This approach allows us to:

  1. Maintain a single source of truth for SAP data within SAC.
  2. Leverage Power BI's advanced visualization capabilities for non-SAP data.
  3. Use Snowflake as the central data warehouse to integrate data across the organization.

Which Tool Should Be the First Point of Enterprise Access?

The answer depends on your organization's priorities:

  • If SAP integration is key: Start with SAP Fiori Launchpad or SAP Work Zone, depending on whether you need transactional access or a collaborative digital workplace.
  • If analytics is the focus: Use SAP Analytics Cloud for SAP data and Power BI or Tableau for non-SAP data.
  • If collaboration and integration are critical: SAP Work Zone is the clear winner, providing a unified interface for SAP and non-SAP tools.

Visualizing the Decision: A Comparison Chart & Decision Tree

To make this easier, here‚Äôs a quick comparison chart:

Feature

SAP Fiori Launchpad

SAP Analytics Cloud

SAP Work Zone

Power BI/Tableau

SAP Integration

Excellent

Excellent

Excellent

Limited

Non-SAP Integration

None

Limited

Analytics Capabilities

Collaboration Features

None

Advanced

SAP Transactions

SAP Analytics

Unified Workplace

Non-SAP Analytics

 

                                                                               Figure: Decision Tree among the available Tools

Final Thoughts

In today's complex analytics environment, there is no single solution that fits every organization. Success lies in aligning technology choices with business objectives, data strategy, and user needs. The most forward-thinking enterprises design flexible analytics ecosystems, balancing governance, agility, and usability to ensure analytics becomes an enabler, not a barrier.

Based on experience across multiple SAP programs, hybrid architectures often offer the strongest foundation. SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) provides deep integration and governance for SAP data, while platforms like Power BI or Tableau enhance visualization and flexibility for non-SAP data sources. Combined with centralized data hubs like Snowflake or SAP Datasphere or SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), this model ensures consistency, scalability, and end-to-end insight.

As SAP continues to innovate, solutions such as SAP Work Zone and the SAC Catalog are transforming how users access, share, and collaborate on analytics content. They bridge the gap between SAP and non-SAP systems, creating a truly unified workspace for both business and IT teams.

Ultimately, the goal is not to choose a single tool but to build an integrated analytics ecosystem, one that empowers users at every level to make data driven decisions confidently. Whether an organization adopts a purely SAP centric approach or a hybrid model, the future of analytics lies in seamless connectivity, collaboration and intelligent decision making.

entry.title: SAP Cloud ALM with SAP Analytics Cloud - Pre-Built "Project Analytics" Dashboard
entry.content:
Are you aware of the SAP Cloud ALM APIs available for projects that can be used to create custom dashboards? Whether you are seeking a customized view for your daily project analysis or you are here out of curiosity, welcome! There is something in this blog for everyone.

On one hand, we have SAP Cloud ALM, which provides access to project data through APIs, covering areas such as requirements, tasks, defects, .... On the other hand, we have SAP Analytics Cloud, which enables the creation of custom dashboards to visualize and analyze this data. By combining data from SAP Cloud ALM with SAP Analytics Cloud, you can develop dedicated dashboards that offer comprehensive insights into project management activities.

Previously, I showcased pre-built dashboards, "Health Analytics" and "Real User Analytics," utilizing data from SAP Cloud ALM Operations in SAP Analytics Cloud. -> Ready-to-Use Template Dashboards: Integrating SAP ... - SAP Community

This time, I want to show you a new pre-built dashboard "Project Analytics", using the data from Implementation part of SAP Cloud ALM.

 

Can you tell me more about this new pre-built dashboard?

The "Project Analytics" dashboard leverages multiple APIs from SAP Cloud ALM, with each API dedicated to specific project elements, such as requirements, tasks, defects, and more. By creating a separate model for each API, I've integrated these data streams into a cohesive dashboard. This approach allows for a comprehensive view of project implementation, combining diverse data points into informative visualizations tailored to enhance project analysis and decision-making.

This pre-built dashboard shows an example of what you can have in SAP Analytics Cloud by using the APIs of SAP Cloud ALM Implementation. It can be use as it is if it suits your needs. But if you are more interested in specifics elements like "Defects" and not that much into "Tasks", it can be customized to focus on your needs. It can be used as a starting point of discussion. This adaptability ensures that the dashboard meets your unique requirements. 

 

What charts does this pre-built dashboard contain?

The "Project Analytics" dashboard is structured to give both an overview and detailed insights into your project implementation. Here's a breakdown of the dashboard sections:

Project Selection and Date Display:

  • At the top right of the dashboard, you can select from the available projects. In this demo, two project data sets are included. Selecting a project synchronizes all charts to show data specific to that project.
  • To the top right again, the date of the data being viewed is displayed. All models in this dashboard get data automatically from SAP Cloud ALM once daily, each morning, this is the default setup for this dashboard.

Project and Element Overview:

  • The second row provides a summary of the project and its key elements, offering a general view without delving into specifics. This includes the total number of items within the project.

  •  It also presents an overview of the status of features and defects, with multiple iterations of similar charts, because why not?

Detailed Element Analysis:

This section offers a more granular look at certain elements, with a focus on Requirements and Tasks for this demo.

Requirements:

  • You have one chart that illustrate the evolution of items created over time.
  • Some numbers that compare item creation on a weekly and monthly basis, demonstrating possible analytical calculations.
  • A chart which shows the distribution of requirements by status and priority, offering a snapshot of the project's current state.
  • A comparison between confirmed requirements this week and last week provides insight into project progress.

 Tasks:

  • You can see a graph which displays the daily evolution of tasks, broken down by status to observe trends and changes.
  • Then on the right is a table showcasing that beyond numbers, Cloud ALM also provides detailed item information. While this demo includes a few columns, additional details like descriptions and assignees can also be displayed and used on others type of charts.

This pre-built dashboard provide both high-level summaries and detailed analyses. It also showed you some capabilities of integrating data from SAP Cloud ALM projects into SAP Analytics Cloud.

 

How to have it on my SAP Analytics Cloud tenant? 

The installation/customization of the "Project Analytics" dashboard is a service provided by SAP. If you're interested in obtaining this dashboard, whether in its current form or customized to meet your specific needs, please reach out to your SAP representative. 

 

Thank you

entry.title: Creating an Import Data Connection to an On-Premise MS SQL Server
entry.content:
In this blog we‚Äôll discuss complete steps that allows you to import data from an on-premise SQL database to SAP Analytics Cloud .

Here, Our Data source is SQL Database from which the SAP Analytics Cloud is connected using the SAP Analytics Cloud Agent and SAP Cloud Connector.

It is recommended that the Cloud Connector, SAP Analytics Cloud agent are installed together on a dedicated server, and not a personal computer. This helps to ensure that multiple users can use an import data connection without experiencing slowness or downtime.

Below are the steps for Import Data connection for On-premise SQL Database ‚Äì

1. Check the connectivity between SAC agent server and SQL DB on the required port.

telnet <MS SQL SERVER> 1433

2. Installing and Configuring SAP Cloud Connector and JVM on a linux server.

  • To install a cloud connector refer the link:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ANALYTICS_CLOUD/00f68c2e08b941f081002fd3691d86a7/ae39ab60b1154c179e2baabd26aa249c.html?locale=en-US&state=PRODUCTION&version=release

  • Make sure a latest JVM version is installed on the Cloud Connector server.

  • To open the SCC, enter: https://<hostname>:8443 in a browser, where the <hostname> is the hostname of the machine on which the connector is installed, and the port number is the one configured during installation. The default port number is 8443
  • Click on ‚ÄúAdd subaccount‚Äù and enter the details of the SAC subaccount , which you can find on SAP Analytics Cloud. To find the Subaccount details of SAP Analytics Cloud :

You must use a System Owner account to perform the following steps. If you don't know who the system owner is, log on to SAP Analytics Cloud and from the side navigation, choose Security > Users. 

 In the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) Account section, enter account ID. In our case SAP Analytics Cloud tenant was hosted on a non-SAP data center, hence our account ID is an email address.

 When the account ID is accepted, account information will be displayed.

Once all the details are entered, your subaccount addition in your Cloud Connector will look like below:

  • Configure System mapping.

Add the internal host name of the Tomcat server where the SAP Analytics Cloud agent is running.

The default Tomcat port is 8080 and the default HTTPS port is 8443.

Enter the virtual host and port so that the internal host name and port are not exposed. 

Agent is reachable.

Add resource.

3. Installing and configuring SAP Analytics Cloud Agent on Linux Server

  • Make sure you have agent installed. To install it you can refer https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ANALYTICS_CLOUD/00f68c2e08b941f081002fd3691d86a7/7c35129451f5432194773adac7f89598.html

You can verify the installation by opening the following URL in your browser: http://<Host>:<Port>/C4A_AGENT/deploymentInfo

The version of the SAP Analytics Cloud agent installed is displayed.

  • Also verify if JRE, Tomcat are installed on the Agent server.

  • Log on to SAP Analytics Cloud with an administrator account.
  • From the side navigation, choose System  Administration -->  Data Source Configuration.
  • In the On-Premise Data Sources section, Add a new location.

You can connect to multiple locations that have on-premises data sources. Each location that you add should already have a Cloud Connector installed and configured on it.

You can also leave the Location ID blank to create a Default Location. This Default location will correspond to your subaccount on the SAP Cloud Connector with a blank Location ID.

  • Make sure Enable Agent is set to ON and enter the virtual hostname and Port that you created during Cloud Connector Configuration along with the Agent username password specified in tomcat-users.xml file.

4. Make sure JDBC driver is installed.

  • Install JDBC drivers if not already based on the JVM version.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/connect/jdbc/download-microsoft-jdbc-driver-for-sql-server?view=sql-server-ver17

The jar files can be in any location on your server as long as the properties file includes the correct file locations.

We kept it in SAC agent installed directory and gave permission 777 and ownership as sidadm:sapsys.

  • Create a properties file that specifies the paths to JDBC drivers you want to use and place it in the same file system where the SAP Analytics Cloud agent is installed. The properties file can have any name, such as DriverConfig.properties.

  1. You must restart the SAP Analytics Cloud agent, using the Java option -DSAP_CLOUD_AGENT_PROPERTIES_PATH since the agent is installed on Linux.

Navigate to tomcat/bin.

Run the shutdown.sh script.

Open the catalina.sh file in the tomcat/bin directory and find the line where Java options are set. Modify this line so that the -DSAP_CLOUD_AGENT_PROPERTIES_PATH option is included and points to your .properties file.

 

Run the startup.sh script.

5. Creating the Import Data Connection in SAC.

entry.title: How to Bulk Modify Calendar Event Context Filters Using Scripting
entry.content:
The Calendar in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) is a powerful framework for orchestrating planning processes, tasks, and workflows across teams. Each calendar event or process carries context filters ‚Äî such as Date, Version, or Proficenter etc. ‚Äî that define the specific slice of data being worked on by a team or user.

In some cases, administrators or power users may need to update these context filters in bulk, for example when moving from one fiscal year to another.

While this can be done manually using the Calendar List workspace (where multiple events can be selected and edited together), alternatively scripting provides a faster, automated way to achieve the same ‚Äî especially when you need to apply changes dynamically.

This approach is inspired by the SAP Community blog written by @mike688 
Experience Sharing ‚Äì How to Batch Modify the Assignees of Calendar Events Using Scripting in SAC, which demonstrates how to modify event assignees in bulk using the Calendar Integration API.

In this post, we extend the same idea ‚Äî but instead of assignees, we modify dimension context filters for multiple events at once.

Option 1 ‚Äì Editing Multiple Events via the SAC UI

You can update context filters directly using the Calendar List workspace:

Steps:

  1. Navigate to Calendar ‚Üí List workspace.

  2. Select multiple events that you want to modify.

  3. Click Edit Events.

  1. Choose Context, and update filters such as Date, Version, or Category.

This method works well for manual batch updates, especially when the changes are straightforward and performed occasionally.For detailed reference, see SAP‚Äôs documentation: Editing Multiple Calendar Events at Once

Option 2 ‚Äì Automating Context Filter Updates Using Scripting

The Calendar Integration API in SAC allows developers to access and modify multiple calendar tasks and processes programmatically.

You can learn more about this API and its supported operations in the official documentation: SAP Help ‚Äì Calendar Event API Reference

Below is an example that demonstrates how to batch modify Date context filters for all child events of a process. You can also modify the same script to change other dimension context filters also.

Example Scenario

Suppose your planning calendar has multiple child tasks for FY2022.
You now want to update all these tasks to FY2025 automatically.

Step 1:  Accessing the EventID of a Process

To view the event ID of an event, go to the Event Settings dialog and choose Show Details. 

Step 2: Create a story and add the below code to the story widget.

Prerequisite: Add a Calendar Integration Technical Object

Then, paste the following script:

 

// Step 1: Get main process event
//Replace XXXXXXX with Process Event ID.
var root = CalendarIntegration_1.getCalendarEventById("XXXXXXXXXXXXX");

if (root === undefined) {
    Application.showMessage(ApplicationMessageType.Warning, "Invalid event ID.");
    Application.hideBusyIndicator();
    return;
}

// Step 2: Check event type
if (root.getType() !== CalendarTaskType.Process) {
    Application.showMessage(ApplicationMessageType.Warning, "Only Process type events can be modified.");
    Application.hideBusyIndicator();
    return;
}

// Step 3: Get children
var process = cast(Type.CalendarProcess, root);
var childIds = process.getChildren();

console.log("Child event IDs:");
console.log(childIds);

var targetYear = "2025"; // Enter Target new year for the child event 

// Step 4: Loop through each childs
for (var i = 0; i < childIds.length; i++) {
    var childId = childIds[i];
    console.log("Processing child ID"+childId);

    var ev = CalendarIntegration_1.getCalendarEventById(childId);
    if (ev === undefined) {
        console.log("Skipping invalid child->"+childId);
		       continue;
    }

    // Step 5: Get context filters
    var ctx = ev.getContextFilters();
    console.log("Context filters for child:");
    console.log(ctx);

    // We can‚Äôt assign null ‚Üí use flag and index instead
    var hasDateFilter = false;
    var dateFilterIndex = -1;

    for (var j = 0; j < ctx.length; j++) {
        var f = ctx[j];
        if (f.members && f.members.length > 0 && f.members[0].dimensionId === "Date") {
            hasDateFilter = true;
            dateFilterIndex = j;
            break;
        }
    }

    if (hasDateFilter === false) {
        console.log("No Date filter found for"+childId);
        continue;
    }

    var dateFilter = ctx[dateFilterIndex];
console.log("datefilter");
	console.log(dateFilter);
    // Step 6: Remove old Date filter for the child event
    var removed = ev.removeContextFilter(dateFilter);
    if (removed === true) {

		console.log("Removed old Date filter for -> " + childId);

    } else {
        //console.log("Could not remove Date filter for:", childId);
        continue;
    }

    // Step 7: Build new Date filter dynamically
    var modelId = dateFilter.members[0].modelId;
    var hierarchy = dateFilter.hierarchy;

	var newDateFilter = ArrayUtils.create(Type.CalendarContextFilter); 
			

	newDateFilter = [{
    hierarchy: {
        id: "FYQP",
        description: "FYQP"
    },
    members: [
        {
            dimensionId: "Date",
            id: "[Date].[FYQP].[Date.FISCAL_YEAR].[" + targetYear + "]",
            description: targetYear,
            displayId: targetYear,
            modelId: modelId
        }
    ]
}];

    // Step 8: Add the new Date filter
  ev.addContextFilter(newDateFilter[0]);
  console.log("Added new Date filter (" + targetYear + ") for" + childId);
}

// Step 9: Done
Application.showMessage(ApplicationMessageType.Success, "Date context filters updated successfully for all child events!");
Application.hideBusyIndicator();

 

API Methods Used

MethodPurpose
getCalendarEventById()Fetches a specific event using its ID
getChildren()Retrieves all child events under a process
getContextFilters()Returns all context filters for the event
removeContextFilter()Removes an existing context filter
addContextFilter()Adds a new context filter dynamically

Summary

The Calendarevent API in SAP Analytics Cloud provides a rich set of methods that go well beyond modifying context filters.
You can reuse the same structure to perform a variety of automation and maintenance actions across the planning calendar events.

By combining UI-based editing and scripting automation, SAC administrators can achieve both flexibility and efficiency in managing planning calendars.

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC): A Beginner's Guide - Part 1
entry.content:
Introduction

Let's understand what is SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC). SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) is a unified data platform which means a single environment that harmonizes information from all SAP and non-SAP sources into a trusted semantic layer. BDC can be the organization's single source of truth which provides a consistent, governed layer of data that everyone can use, whether it‚Äôs for analytics, planning, or building AI Applications. 

 

But the bigger topic is why do we even need something like SAP Business Data Cloud?

Why do we need Business Data Cloud? 

Today every organization is talking about being ‚Äòdata-driven.‚Äô We all want to make decisions based on real insights rather than gut feeling.  But in reality, its not that easy. the truth is data is everywhere. But it's rarely in one place or in one consistent format. Businesses have information scattered across multiple systems . Like some in SAP applications like S/4HANA or SuccessFactors, some in non-SAP platforms, spreadsheets, or even external sources like partners and IoT devices. So when companies try to bring that data together for analytics or AI, they face a few very real challenges.

  1.  How do you build a single, complete data foundation that supports modern AI and machine learning models?
  2.  How do you trust your data? how do you ensure quality, consistency, and integrity so that the decisions you make are actually reliable?
  3.  How do you extract real business value from this massive, mixed pool of structured and unstructured data?

SAP recognized that these are the exact pain points stopping companies from truly using data to their advantage. And that‚Äôs what led to the creation of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC).

One of the major innovations behind BDC is how it eliminates data fragmentation. Instead of moving data between systems and losing context along the way, BDC integrates data in real time while preserving its business meaning. For example, if the same business entity, say a customer exists in multiple SAP systems, BDC brings together under a unified definition using the One Domain Model. So business users don't have to worry about where the data came from or how it's structured. They simply work with consistent, harmonized business entities that are ready for analytics, reporting, or Artificial Intelligence (AI). 

The best part is SAP fully manages the entire lifecycle. BDC is delivered as a Software-as-a-Service solution built on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).  Because of that all the integration, replication, and governance are handled by SAP. In the past, customers had to manually extract and prepare SAP data before it was usable for analytics. That process was slow, expensive, and error-prone. With BDC, that‚Äôs all automated so organizations can focus their time and resources on building innovative AI models, automating insights, or improving business performance instead of just wrangling data.

Let's take a practical scenario, imagine a large enterprise with data coming from ERP, HR, procurement, and expense systems. Traditionally, every system had its own data units, and teams had to spend weeks just preparing the data before running any kind of analysis. Now, with SAP Business Data Cloud, all of that data whether it‚Äôs from SAP S/4HANA, SuccessFactors, Ariba, Concur, or even non-SAP systems can be harmonized and made available in one place instantly. That gives the business a 360-degree view across operations, employees, customers, and suppliers. The platform supports a wide range of use cases from data warehousing and BI, to AI and machine learning, planning, governance, and even intelligent application development. Basically, it‚Äôs an end-to-end solution that connects data and intelligence across the entire organization. The real value, however, is in the trust and governance that come built-in. Because BDC leverages SAP‚Äôs domain expertise and semantic understanding of business data, it ensures that what you see in your reports and AI models actually reflects reality not inconsistent or duplicate information.

So to sum it up, SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) transforms how organizations manage and use their data. It addresses the three biggest challenges of the data-driven world:

  1.  Building a single, reliable foundation for AI and analytics
  2.  Ensuring data trust and quality
  3.  Unlocking the full value of structured and unstructured data across the enterprise

It's like a bridge that connects all the data sources, both internal and external into one governed, business-ready environment. In other words, it takes us from data chaos to clarity. It helps organizations move beyond just having data, to truly using it to drive growth, innovation, and intelligent decision-making.

Key Components of SAP Business Data Cloud

Let's see how BDC is built and how the key components that make it work and how they fit together.

One of the most interesting things about SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) is that it doesn't start from scratch. It combines some of SAP's most proven existing technologies with brand new innovations designed for the data and AI era.

Let's understand the existing SAP solutions that form the foundation. 

SAP Datasphere - This is one of the core data integration and modeling layer of BDC.  It is like a brain that organises, connects, and models all the business data. Datasphere allows you to define data models, map relationships, and create semantic layers that business and technical users can both understand. It‚Äôs the part of the platform that ensures data is structured, contextualized, and ready to use for analytics and AI.

SAP Analytics Cloud - This is the analysis and visualization layer. It‚Äôs where users actually interact with data through dashboards, reports, and planning models. SAC is tightly integrated with BDC.  It provides both out-of-the-box analytical stories and flexible tools for ad-hoc analysis. It even supports AI-driven features like predictive insights and chat-based data exploration, helping users move seamlessly from insight to action.

SAP BW or BW/4HANA -  Many customers already have large investments in BW, and SAP recognized that value. So instead of replacing it, BDC integrates it. BW data objects can be technically onboarded into the Business Data Cloud, as data products and reuse them in new AI and analytics scenarios. SAP plans to support BW until 2030, but the idea is to give customers a smooth modernization path toward BW/4HANA and cloud-native analytics.

Now let's understand the new components introduced specifically for SAP Business Data Cloud. 

SAP Databricks - This is one of the biggest innovations. It brings advanced AI and machine learning capabilities directly into the SAP ecosystem. Databricks has long been a leader in large-scale data processing and pro-code data science, and SAP has now embedded a tailored version inside BDC.
This integration allows data scientists to access and extend data products directly. For example, they can take a data product from SAP Business Data Cloud, enrich it with machine learning models in Databricks, and then push the enhanced insights right back into the BDC catalog or vice versa.

SAP Business Data Cloud Foundation Services - This layer manages the data lifecycle from ingestion and harmonization to transformation and enrichment. When data comes from your source systems (for example, SAP S/4HANA Cloud or SAP SuccessFactors) the Foundation Services replicate it into the BDC environment, which runs on SAP HANA Cloud and hyper-scaler infrastructure. From there, it‚Äôs automatically cleansed, harmonized, and turned into something called a data product which a packaged, ready-to-use set of business data.

Conclusion

Now we have covered the Introduction, Why do we need Business Data Cloud, and Key Components of SAP Business Data Cloud. I hope you have got a basic understanding about SAP Business Data Cloud. This is the first part of the blog series.

In the upcoming parts, we will cover the architecture of SAP Business Data Cloud, and understand the main components of BDC in detail.

If you have any questions or queries, please post them as comments. I will try to answer the maximum as per my knowledge.

entry.title: TechEd 2025 in Berlin - Recap on planning in SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
It has already been a week since I boarded my train home from Berlin after an exciting TechEd 2025. Coming back from such an event always feels a bit like returning to reality ‚Äî all the nicer to look back on the sessions I had the honor of hosting and the great conversations with customers and partners in the meeting center, at the demo booth, and beyond. 

In case you missed TechEd, don't worry. We have got you covered. 

Virtual Sessions:

Together with @jie_deng  and @matthiaskraemer, I hosted session DA207 - Planning and analytics: Innovations powering SAP Business Data Cloud which is available on-demand on the TechEd virtual website (registration required). We had a full house, lots of interesting questions and loads of live demos (and no demo system let us down üôè). We discussed the overall strategy of SAP Analytics Cloud in the context of SAP Business Data Cloud. On the planning side, we gave an outlook on our priorities for 2026 and highlighted recent innovations in seamless planning and GenAI. We could also showcase great new features like MyMetrics, Horizon theme support and provided a labs preview at how we want to further empower the story designer in SAP Analytics Cloud. 

Besides, I recommend these sessions (again, registration is required):

Session ID & NameSpeakersLink
ST107v | SAP Business Data Cloud: Strategy, architecture, and visionTorsten Ammon
SVP - Head of Business Data Cloud Core 
Prakash Nanduri
Global Head of Product Management BDC&I
Link
DA806v | SAP Business Data Cloud solution road mapTorsten Ammon
SVP - Head of Business Data Cloud Core 
Kristian R√ºmmelin
SAP Business Data Cloud - Head of Product Management Planning & Analytics,		Link
DA203v | SAP Business Data Cloud: The path forward for SAP Business WarehouseDominik Kurz
Product Expert SAP BW/4HANA & SAP BW Bridge
Klaus-Peter Sauer
Product Management SAP Business Data Cloud		 Link
Hands-on

Our hands-on workshop DA267 - Seamless planning for xP&A in SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC) was another highlight. Preparing such sessions is a big task but it always is worth the effort. Luckily, I was supported by @jie_deng and @Matthew_Shaw who supported the preparation, the testing, and the session itself. The new live version feature for seamless planning was front and center in the workshop. Participants learned how to:

  • Build a seamless planning model from a view that is part of content shipped with Working Capital Insights Intelligent Application
  • Expose plan data in SAP Datasphere and bring it together with actual data in an analytic model
  • Extend the model with xP&A data and leverage the live version for calculations

The exercise and the tenants are still available! Check it out!

Exercise flow

Thanks to everyone for joining TechEd and for your interest in our content! Looking forward to 2026 already.
